background_dashed.customLabel: In Adolescents (13-19 years old),  participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of rTMS on Restricted/repetitive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 4 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adolescents (13-19 years old),  participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of rTMS on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 3 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adolescents (13-19 years old),  participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of rTMS on ADHD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 3 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adolescents (13-19 years old),  participants, there is a very strong effect in favor of  rTMS on Disruptive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 3 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.
